unnormalised: Okay, folks, let's talk about the bane of every office worker's existence: scheduling! Specifically, how to *not* make everyone want to pre-pone their own funerals when you're in charge of organizing meetings and deadlines.
normalised: Okay, folks, let's talk about the bane of every office worker's existence: scheduling! Specifically, how to not make everyone want to pre-pone their own funerals when you're in charge of organizing meetings and deadlines.

unnormalised: First things first, stop sending out meeting requests for 3:00 AM IST. I know, I know, sometimes you're coordinating with overseas teams, but seriously, check the time zones! Someone in Bangalore isn't going to appreciate a 1:30 AM call with New York. Use a timezone converter!
normalised: First things first, stop sending out meeting requests for three A-M I-S-T. I know, I know, sometimes you're coordinating with overseas teams, but seriously, check the time zones! Someone in Bangalore isn't going to appreciate a one thirty A-M call with New York. Use a timezone converter!

unnormalised: And speaking of meetings, is it *really* necessary? I mean, does that 15min check-in actually need to be on the calendar? Can't it be a quick WhatsApp message instead? Think about the time you're stealing from people! Reduce it to essential meetings.
normalised: And speaking of meetings, is it really necessary? I mean, does that fifteen minute check-in actually need to be on the calendar? Can't it be a quick WhatsApp message instead? Think about the time you're stealing from people! Reduce it to essential meetings.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole deadline situation. Don't just randomly pick a date like 26/01/2025, without considering the project's scope or the team's workload. Talk to people! Get their input. Nobody wants to be scrambling to finish something at 11:59 PM on a Sunday. And honestly, try to avoid deadlines on weekends if you can.
normalised: Then there's the whole deadline situation. Don't just randomly pick a date like twenty sixth January two thousand and twenty five, without considering the project's scope or the team's workload. Talk to people! Get their input. Nobody wants to be scrambling to finish something at eleven fifty nine P-M on a Sunday. And honestly, try to avoid deadlines on weekends if you can.

unnormalised: Also, be realistic about time estimates. That task that you think will take 2 hours? It'll probably take 4. Always factor in buffer time for unexpected delays, because let's be honest, something *always* goes wrong. Especially on Mondays.
normalised: Also, be realistic about time estimates. That task that you think will take two hours? It'll probably take four. Always factor in buffer time for unexpected delays, because let's be honest, something always goes wrong. Especially on Mondays.

unnormalised: Remember, that time is money. Money for your company and more importantly, time is precious for your colleagues!
normalised: Remember, that time is money. Money for your company and more importantly, time is precious for your colleagues!

unnormalised: Don't forget to factor in public holidays! Scheduling a crucial meeting on Diwali (Oct/27/2025) is a surefire way to annoy everyone. Check the government calendar and be mindful of regional festivals too. Kerala might be celebrating Onam while the rest of the country is working.
normalised: Don't forget to factor in public holidays! Scheduling a crucial meeting on Diwali (October twenty seventh two thousand and twenty five) is a surefire way to annoy everyone. Check the government calendar and be mindful of regional festivals too. Kerala might be celebrating Onam while the rest of the country is working.

unnormalised: Next, use calendar tools effectively. Google Calendar, Microsoft Outlook, whatever your company uses, learn its features! Set reminders, use different colors for different types of events, and for the love of all that is holy, update the calendar when things change! I hate it when I see a meeting at 10:00 AM, when it was changed to 11:30 AM.
normalised: Next, use calendar tools effectively. Google Calendar, Microsoft Outlook, whatever your company uses, learn its features! Set reminders, use different colors for different types of events, and for the love of all that is holy, update the calendar when things change! I hate it when I see a meeting at ten A-M, when it was changed to eleven thirty A-M.

unnormalised: And please, for the sake of everyone's sanity, send out agendas *before* the meeting. Nobody wants to show up to a meeting and have no idea what's going to be discussed. A clear agenda helps people prepare and makes the meeting more productive.
normalised: And please, for the sake of everyone's sanity, send out agendas before the meeting. Nobody wants to show up to a meeting and have no idea what's going to be discussed. A clear agenda helps people prepare and makes the meeting more productive.

unnormalised: Be responsive! Things change. Deadlines shift. Meetings get preponed. If someone emails you to ask about a scheduling conflict, don't ignore them! A quick reply can save a lot of headaches down the road. Nobody wants to work till 3:30 am to meet a deadline that can be preponed.
normalised: Be responsive! Things change. Deadlines shift. Meetings get preponed. If someone emails you to ask about a scheduling conflict, don't ignore them! A quick reply can save a lot of headaches down the road. Nobody wants to work till three thirty A-M to meet a deadline that can be preponed.

unnormalised: Finally, be empathetic! Remember that everyone has lives outside of work. Be understanding if someone needs to reschedule a meeting due to a personal emergency or a prior commitment. A little bit of flexibility can go a long way in building goodwill and fostering a positive work environment. Plus, what goes around comes around.
normalised: Finally, be empathetic! Remember that everyone has lives outside of work. Be understanding if someone needs to reschedule a meeting due to a personal emergency or a prior commitment. A little bit of flexibility can go a long way in building goodwill and fostering a positive work environment. Plus, what goes around comes around.

unnormalised: So, there you have it. A few simple tips to help you schedule like a pro and avoid turning your colleagues into raging lunatics. Happy scheduling!
normalised: So, there you have it. A few simple tips to help you schedule like a pro and avoid turning your colleagues into raging lunatics. Happy scheduling!
